content: # Gas Supply System Fault Finding Guide

This comprehensive guide covers diagnostic procedures for gas supply systems, addressing issues with Emergency Control Valves (ECVs), meters, governors, pipe sizing, pressure drop, leakage detection, and system testing.
- **Emergency Control Valve (ECV)**: Main shut-off valve at property boundary
- **Appliance Isolation Valves**: Local shut-offs for each appliance
- **District Governor**: Reduces pressure for local distribution
- **Service Pipe**: Connection from main to property boundary
- **Mains Pressure**: Typically 21-75mbar medium pressure or higher
- **Standing Pressure**: System pressure when no gas flowing
- Higher calorific value than natural gas
- Heavier than air (collects at low points if leaked)
- Partial gas flow despite open valve
- Check for external damage or corrosion
- Verify valve handle moves freely (don't force)
- Look for signs of leakage (corrosion, discoloration)
- Check handle alignment with gas flow when open/closed
- Listen for abnormal noises during operation
- Apply leak detection fluid around valve body and connections
- Watch for bubbles indicating gas escape
- NEVER use a naked flame to test
- Use electronic gas detector for verification
- Symptoms: Cannot turn valve or requires excessive force
- Cause: Age, corrosion, lack of use
- Solution: Do not force; requires replacement by gas supplier
- Symptoms: Gas smell, bubbles with detection fluid
- Cause: Damaged seals, loose connections, cracked valve body
- Solution: Contact gas supplier immediately; do not attempt repair
- Symptoms: Reduced gas flow, appliance underperformance
- Solution: Requires replacement by gas supplier
- Must be easily accessible at all times
- Location must be known to all building occupants
- Must be properly sized for maximum gas flow rate
- Must be capable of being operated by persons with normal physical abilities
- Never modify or tamper with valve
- Educate all building users on location and operation
- Clearly mark location if not obvious
- Read manually or via smart technology
- Common issues: Stuck mechanisms, damaged displays, leaking connections
- Common issues: Display failures, communication errors, battery problems
- Common issues: Card/key reading problems, valve failures, credit display errors
- Run a single appliance for known time
- Verify digits/dials are moving when gas is flowing
- Check for error codes on digital/smart meters
- Check inlet and outlet connections for tightness
- Apply leak detection fluid to all joints
- Symptoms: Meter doesn't register gas use
- Solution: Report to gas supplier for replacement
- Symptoms: Gas smell, positive leak detection
- Solution: Report to gas supplier immediately
- Symptoms: Fluctuating gas pressure, appliance issues
- Solution: Requires replacement by gas supplier
- Symptoms: Prepayment meter showing incorrect balance
- Solution: Contact supplier; may need to add emergency credit
- Not in sleeping areas (unless in sealed, ventilated compartment)
- Not in escape routes unless in fire-protected enclosure
- Inadequate support causing strain on connections
- Improper sealing of ducts entering property
- Exposure to water or corrosive environments
- Standing pressure test (should maintain pressure for minimum 1 minute)
- Let-by test of meter control valve
- Test downstream pressure at test point
- Check at zero flow and at maximum flow
- Check for excessive pressure drop under load
- Check governor vent is not blocked
- Ensure vent line terminates in safe location if extended
- Check for vibration under varying load
- Verify stable pressure during appliance cycling
- Check for gas smell indicating diaphragm failure
- Symptoms: Appliance performance issues, yellow flames
- Cause: Governor drift, damaged valve seat
- Solution: Adjustment if permitted, otherwise replacement
- Symptoms: Gas smell from vent, continuous gas flow
- Cause: Damaged valve seat or diaphragm
- Cause: Insect nests, debris, ice formation
- Solution: Clear blockage; replace if damaged
- Symptoms: Significant pressure drop under load, appliance starvation
- Cause: Insufficient capacity for connected load
- Solution: Replace with correctly sized unit
- Symptoms: Poor regulation at low flow, hunting (pressure oscillation)
- Cause: Operating below minimum design flow
- Solution: Replace with correctly sized unit or modify system
- Verify outlet pressure at zero flow
- Test pressure stability under varying load
## PART 5: PIPE SIZING AND BLOCKAGE ISSUES
- Pressure drop when multiple appliances operate
- Measure pipe lengths and identify restrictions
- Use pipe sizing tables to verify adequacy
- Compare existing pipe sizes with requirements
- Calculate pressure drop per meter of pipe
- Check against maximum allowed (typically 1mbar for entire system)
- Run appliances one at a time, starting with closest to meter
- Note pressure drop with each additional load
- Symptoms: System once adequate now fails
- Cause: Added appliances without upgrading pipework
- Solution: Recalculate system and upgrade pipework as needed
- Symptoms: Similar to undersizing but in specific sections
- Cause: Debris, pipe damage, improper fittings
- Solution: Locate restriction and repair/replace section
- Symptoms: System mostly works but fails at peak demand
- Cause: One undersize section creating bottleneck
- Solution: Identify and upgrade critical section
- Corrosion products (especially in older steel pipes)
- Test pressure before and after suspected blockage
- Work methodically through system to pinpoint
- Measure time to pass known volume of gas
- Process of elimination to identify blocked section
- Only suitable for minor, loose debris
- Must be performed by qualified person
- New pipe installed to current standards
- Installation of dirt traps at strategic points
- Elimination of low points where condensate collects
- Some pressure drop is unavoidable in any flowing system
- Normal drop: Less than 1mbar across entire system
- Excessive: More than 2mbar or causing appliance malfunction
- Critical: Any drop causing appliance safety device activation
- With all appliances off, measure pressure at meter outlet
- Should equal regulator outlet pressure (21mbar NG, 37mbar LPG)
- Measure pressure at appliance with all appliances running
- Compare with minimum required for appliance
- Calculate total system drop (standing minus working)
- Measure pressure at two points of known pipe distance
- Calculate drop per meter of pipe
- Compare with theoretical values based on flow rate
- Monitor pressure while cycling appliances on/off
- Note recovery time after appliances shut down
- Symptoms: System once adequate, gradually worsening
- Solution: Systematic testing to identify affected sections
- Cause: Higher demand, possible condensate freezing
- Solution: Insulation, capacity upgrade, condensate traps
- Cause: Often regulator problems or variable upstream supply
- Solution: Extended monitoring to identify pattern
- Bubbling in standing water near pipes
- Abnormal meter movement when no appliances running
- Systematic visual check of all accessible pipework
- Listen for hissing, particularly at joints
- Apply approved leak detection fluid to all joints
- Pay particular attention to threaded connections
- Test at multiple heights (NG rises, LPG falls)
- Isolate system and pressurize slightly above working pressure
- Monitor for pressure drop over time (10 minutes minimum)
- Smaller sections can be tested to pinpoint location
- Look for pipe damage at compression point
- Check for cracking, particularly near fittings
- Check for correct type (cooker, boiler, etc.)
- Look for leakage when valve operated
- Verify proper valve type for application
- Small bubble formation over several seconds
- No detectable gas smell unless very close
- Usually fixable by tightening or resealing
- Audible or detectable with electronic device
- Immediate bubble stream with detection fluid
- Requires emergency isolation and professional repair
- Do not operate electrical switches or create ignition sources
- Commercial applications may use higher pressures
- Outside these ranges, appliance performance and safety affected
- Measure at appliance test point while running
- Test at both minimum and maximum firing rates
- Measure at both inlet to appliance and burner manifold
- Significant difference indicates appliance regulator issue
| Component | Parameter | Natural Gas | LPG (Propane) | LPG (Butane) |
| Meter | Allowable Leakage | Zero | Zero | Zero |
| Maximum Gas Load (kW) | Maximum Run (m) | Mild Steel Pipe Size | Copper Pipe Size |
*Note: This is simplified; actual sizing depends on specific installation details*
### Common Test Points and Pressure Readings
| Test Location | Expected Reading (NG) | Common Issues if Abnormal |
| Meter Outlet | 21mbar | Regulator failure, utility issue |
| After ECV | 21mbar | ECV restriction, utility issue |
| Before Appliance Isolation | 20-21mbar | Pipe sizing, blockage |
| Appliance Test Point | 20mbar | Appliance regulator, valve issue |
| Burner Manifold | Model-specific | Injector blockage, valve issue |
- Work must be performed by Gas Safe registered engineer
- Know location of all isolation points
- Use of intrinsically safe equipment where required
